sub_topic: Finding the period and amplitude of trigonometric functions
message_1: A Ferris wheel has a radius of 30 meters and completes one full rotation every 60 seconds. Using trigonometry, determine the amplitude and period of the sinusoidal function that represents the height of a passenger over time if they get on at the bottom of the wheel.
message_2:
To represent the height of a passenger on a Ferris wheel using a sinusoidal function, we can use the sine function. The general form of a sine function is:

h(t) = A * sin(B(t - C)) + D

where h(t) is the height of the passenger at time t, A is the amplitude, B is the frequency, C is the phase shift, and D is the vertical shift.

In this case, the Ferris wheel has a radius of 30 meters, so the amplitude A is equal to the radius, which is 30 meters. This is because the height of the passenger will oscillate between 0 and 60 meters, with the maximum height difference being 60 meters.

The period of the Ferris wheel is the time it takes to complete one full rotation, which is given as 60 seconds. The period is related to the frequency B by the formula:

Period = 2π / B

So, we can find the frequency B as follows:

B = 2π / Period = 2π / 60 = π / 30

Since the passenger gets on at the bottom of the wheel, there is no phase shift (C = 0).

The vertical shift D is equal to the radius of the Ferris wheel because the height of the passenger oscillates around the center of the wheel, which is at a height of 30 meters.

Putting all these values together, we get the sinusoidal function representing the height of the passenger over time:

h(t) = 30 * sin(π/30 * t) + 30
